subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: ... Sure.  But th-fronting, which merges thin and fin and began in Cockney, has now spread outward and upmarket, though it has not of course taken over the
messageBody:
Moira O'Brien scripsit:

> Sorry John - as a South Eastern England speaker, Thaw-Et-Fee-Tea and
> Fee-Et-Fee-Tee are two different sounds.

Sure. But th-fronting, which merges "thin" and "fin" and began in
Cockney, has now spread outward and upmarket, though it has not of course
taken over the whole "Estuary" area, in particular, older speakers are
less affected than younger ones, and the middle class less than other
classes.

> I find I am getting very confused with the names for the letters which
> you are all using. I know the QM names, and I have all John Zuk's
> names (which I like) but I dont understand these new names you all
> seem to be using. Where do they come from?

I can only speak for myself. I use the QM letter names exclusively,
capitalized like Tea, Fee, etc. (Occasionally I make mistakes like Tee
instead of Tea.)

The all-caps words like KIT, DRESS, etc. don't refer to letters, but to
lexical sets: groups of English words all of which have the same vowel in
a particular accent. All the words in the KIT set have the same vowel in
a given accent, even though it may be quite a different sound from one
accent to another. Some sets, like BATH, are pronounced like one set
(PALM) in some accents, like another set (TRAP) in other accents.

Accents of English can be characterized by which lexical sets are
"merged", or pronounced the same. For example, current versions of RP
merge CLOTH = LOT, BATH = PALM = START, THOUGHT = NORTH = FORCE = CURE,
and LETTER = COMMA (unstressed vowel). Some speakers don't merge CURE.
Not all accents are properly handled by the standard lexical sets: for
example, Welsh English never merged GOOSE and JUICE, but the lexical
set JUICE is not needed for any other accent and is omitted from the
standard list.

You can read more about the standard lexical sets at
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_history_of_English_consonants#Dental_fricatives .

--
Long-short-short, long-short-short / Dactyls in dimeter, John Cowan
Verse form with choriambs / (Masculine rhyme): cowan@...
One sentence (two stanzas) / Hexasyllabically
Challenges poets who / Don't have the time. --robison who's at texas dot net
